entry.title: Pure Functions
entry.content:
The hardest problem in software engineering (aside from choosing which program to write) is keeping your program simple enough for maintainers to confidently read, understand, and make changes to. This problem is called ‚Äúmanaging complexity,‚Äù and there are lots of famous quotes about it1. Managing complexity is easy when a program is small, but it gets exponentially harder as years pass, the program gets bigger, the engineering organization gets bigger too, and the program‚Äôs original authors leave.

Pure functions are my favorite tool for managing complexity. Let‚Äôs talk about what they are and why they‚Äôre so effective. Note: I‚Äôll be showing examples in Python, but you can write pure functions in any programming language.

What is a pure function?

We call a function ‚Äúpure‚Äù if it follows these two rules:

  1. It always returns the same outputs when given the same inputs.
  2. It performs no side effects.

Here are some examples of what I mean when I say ‚Äúside effects‚Äù:

  • Mutating one of the function‚Äôs arguments
  • Mutating a global variable
  • Reading/writing to a database
  • Making an HTTP request
  • Sending an email
  • Sending a push notification
  • Firing a missile

Examples

This is a pure function:




This function is impure:







This one‚Äôs super impure:







Primary Benefit



We have to put away some our tools when we write pure functions: we can‚Äôt read from the database, we can‚Äôt check what time it is, we can‚Äôt pull an API key from a global config object. What do we get in return?



The primary benefit of pure functions is that they are simple enough to fit into your head. In order to understand what a pure function does, you just need to look at these things:



    
  
  • What are the function‚Äôs inputs?
    • 
  
  • What are the function‚Äôs outputs?
    • 




By contrast, here are some of the things that you need to think about when you‚Äôre reading an impure function:



    
  
  • What are the function‚Äôs inputs?
    
      
      
    • When the function has finished running, what state will the inputs be in?
      • 
      
    • Will some of the inputs have been mutated? Which ones?
      • 
      
    • Will the inputs be mutated every time the function runs, or only sometimes?
      • 
    
    
  
    • 
  
  • What are the function‚Äôs outputs? Does it have any?
    • 
  
  • What global variables does the function read from?
    
      
      
    • Have those global variables been initialized the way that we expect by the time that this function is called?
      • 
      
    • What happens if they haven‚Äôt?
      • 
    
    
  
    • 
  
  • What global variables does the function write to?
    
      
      
    • How does that affect the other parts of the program that read those variables?
      • 
    
    
  
    • 
  
  • What if the database is unreachable?
    • 
  
  • What if the API we‚Äôre calling is down?
    • 
  
  • What day of the week is it?
    • 
  
  • What is the phase of the moon as seen from Mars?
    
      
      
    • Which moon?
      • 
    
    
  
    • 




When working with pure functions, you can think about the function in isolation and don‚Äôt have to worry about fitting the rest of the program into your head. I‚Äôve heard this described as ‚Äúlocal reasoning‚Äù (which pure functions enable you to do), as opposed to ‚Äúglobal reasoning‚Äù (which impure code forces you to do).



Secondary Benefits



As if that weren‚Äôt enough, you also get these things for free:



    
  
  • Pure functions are safe to cache, since the same inputs always give the same outputs.
    • 
  
  • Pure functions are safe to parallelize, since they don‚Äôt mutate anything.
    • 
  
  • Pure functions are trivial to test, since you don‚Äôt need to mock anything.
    • 




Let‚Äôs zoom in on that last bullet point, because the difference is really unbelievable. Here‚Äôs a test for the pure function I showed you earlier:







Here‚Äôs a test for the one of the impure functions:







Which of these two worlds would you rather live in?



General Advice



It‚Äôs easiest to write pure functions when you‚Äôre working with ‚Äúplain data,‚Äù i.e. stuff that doesn‚Äôt have an active connection to the database. You can still make a function pure even if it‚Äôs operating on database models, though: as long as your function follows the two rules we talked about earlier, it‚Äôs pure!



I‚Äôll bet that a lot of functions in your codebase are just one or two tweaks away from purity. As you get in the habit of looking for side effects, you‚Äôll get better at identifying them and eliminating them. For example: does your function really need to modify its inputs and return None? What if it left its inputs unmodified and returned a value instead?



Of course, not every side effect can be removed. We write and run programs because they do stuff! For now, just focus on finding and eliminating the side effects that don‚Äôt need to happen (and the ones that don‚Äôt need to happen in this specific function). Next time we‚Äôll talk about how to handle the side effects that remain!



Appendix: Smells To Watch Out For



    
  
  • If a function takes no inputs, it‚Äôs probably impure.
    • 
  
  • If a function has no output, it‚Äôs probably impure.
    • 
  
  • If a function is async, it‚Äôs probably impure.
    • 
  
  • If you need to use mocks when testing a function, it‚Äôs probably impure.
    • 




References


    
  
  • Hoist Your I/O
    • 
  
  • Functional Core, Imperative Shell (Scott Wlaschin version)
    • 
  
  • This refactoring exercise from ‚ÄúSolving Problems the Clojure Way‚Äù - I love the visualization technique the presenter uses, it makes it really easy to follow the side effects as they get moved or eliminated.
    • 
  
  • Functional Programming in C++ (by John Carmack!!)
    •

    Edsger Dijkstra: ‚ÄúThe computing scientist‚Äôs main challenge is not to get confused by the complexities of his own making.‚Äù Steve McConnell: ‚ÄúManaging complexity is the most important technical topic in software development.‚Äù Ben Moseley and Peter Marks: ‚ÄúComplexity is the single major difficulty in the successful development of large-scale software systems.‚Äù Dr. Pamela Zave: ‚ÄúThe purpose of software engineering is to control complexity, not to create it.‚Äù Bruce Eckel: ‚ÄúProgramming is about managing complexity: the complexity of the problem, laid upon the complexity of the machine. Because of this complexity, most of our programming projects fail.‚Äù¬†↩

entry.title: Book Report: Architecture Patterns with Python
entry.content:
I recently read Architecture Patterns with Python. The book‚Äôs primary focus is on how to structure programs so that they stay simple and maintainable as they grow: that‚Äôs my specific favorite programming topic, so of course I liked it. I‚Äôm probably not going to use the exact techniques that the authors recommend in this book, but they discussed some cool ideas that reminded me of things I‚Äôve run into at past jobs, and the book‚Äôs available for free online, so what‚Äôs not to like?

The book discusses domain-driven design and an event-driven architecture (potentially, but not necessarily, a microservices-based one). I‚Äôm going to talk a bit about some of my favorite ideas from the book, but I want to knock out a few odds and ends before we get there:

Side Notes

  • It was a relatively fast read - nice clear prose, nice short chapters.
  • The book didn‚Äôt make me a total expert in DDD, but that‚Äôs OK1.
  • The authors were careful to not wholeheartedly recommend microservices, which I appreciated.
  • Each chapter had a short pros/cons table at the end with some really frank discussion of whether or not the technique discussed in that chapter could be worth applying in your own work. Many of the ‚Äúcons‚Äù sections looked something like this, and I appreciated their candor:
    • ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been at pains to point out that each pattern comes at a cost. Each layer of indirection has a price in terms of complexity and duplication in our code and will be confusing to programmers who‚Äôve never seen these patterns before.‚Äù

OK, on to the good stuff.

Value Objects

The book recommends using ‚Äúvalue objects‚Äù to represent core primitive business concepts, and suggests using dataclasses to do it. Here‚Äôs an example from Chapter 1:




I also recommend doing this. The important thing here is that this class doesn‚Äôt know anything about a database/ORM - it‚Äôs just a simple dataclass that refers to some other simple dataclasses. It‚Äôs really easy to write nice, easy-to-test pure functions that operate on data like this. In an ideal world, this is what all of your core primitives would look like.



This brings us to our next topic, which is extremely related:



Dependency Inversion Principle



This term was new to me. Apparently it‚Äôs an OO thing (it‚Äôs the D in SOLID?), and I don‚Äôt find the original formulation super helpful, but the authors translate it into a technique that I find very compelling. It‚Äôs easiest to demonstrate that technique by contrast to the previous example.



Instead of using the ‚Äúvalue object‚Äù technique, most of the codebases I‚Äôve worked in have used models like this to represent their core primitives:







In a system like this, the vast majority of your code operates directly on these database-focused models, which makes it a lot harder to reliably write pure functions. Instead, you tend to end up with code that‚Äôs littered with lots of little reads+writes to the database. Code written this way is hard to unit test (because you have to patch out all of those database interactions), and it tends to grow in complexity over time as maintainers add more and more little reads and writes, because what‚Äôs the harm in just one more?



The authors say that instead of using database-focused models as the core primitives of your system, you should use simple pure-Python data structures like the frozen dataclass you saw earlier, and your database models should be derived from those pure-Python models. To put it another way:




  
The ORM imports (or ‚Äúdepends on‚Äù or ‚Äúknows about‚Äù) the domain model, and not the other way around.





I‚Äôd love to work in a system like this someday :)



Pure Functions



Pure functions2 come up now and then throughout the book, although I don‚Äôt remember the authors spending much time addressing the topic head-on. That‚Äôs OK, because the book does a great job of showing them in action.



For instance, Chapter 3 focuses on a program for syncing files between two directories, and the authors are trying to figure out how to make it easy to test. At first, the whole program is concerned with operating directly on the file system, and so in all their tests they have to spin up some temporary directories and write a bunch of files to them and call the program and then examine what it did to the temporary directories. Ick!



Then they propose a different approach: ‚Äú[w]e‚Äôre going to separate what we want to do from how to do it‚Äù. They change the core of their program so that it takes two dicts as input, each representing the files in a directory:







And to go along with that, their program now returns a list of operations that it wants to perform in order to sync the two directories:







In order to test the sync algorithm, the authors don‚Äôt have to read from and write to the file system any more - they can just pass a couple of dicts into the program, examine the data that it returns as output, and check to see if the program wants to do the right thing. The dicts and tuples that their tests use are trivial to construct, no side effects or mocking/patching necessary.



There‚Äôs still some code at the edges of their program that a) examines the file system to create those input dicts and b) modifies the file system based off of the instructions in those output commands, but that‚Äôs an unavoidable fact of life; the main thing that matters is that the bulk of the program is now side-effect-free. Lovely!



This approach is often called ‚Äúfunctional core, imperative shell‚Äù3, which is the idea that the bulk of your program should be pure functions with a thin layer at the edges for actually interacting with the real world. I like this idea very much üôÇ



Conclusion



This book was pretty decent, I‚Äôd give it 3.5 stars. I‚Äôm not going to go write an event-driven microservice-based system with lots of DDD techniques, but it was fun to hear the authors talk about those topics, and I enjoyed their treatment of the ideas above!




  
    
    
  1. 
      
    I have Scott Wlaschin‚Äôs ‚ÄúDomain Modeling Made Functional‚Äù on my desk, and am hoping that that book‚Äôll be the one that finally makes DDD click for me. I love his talks on YouTube, I need to go back and watch them all. Brilliant guy.¬†↩

entry.title: Getting High Schoolers To Write A Tiny 'Roguelike' In An Intro Python Class
entry.content:
I spent the past couple years volunteering in a couple of tech classes at a local high school, primarily in an introductory Python class led by an excellent teacher named Tamara O‚ÄôMalley. I‚Äôve written about this a few times before.1 It was extremely fun, and it still hasn‚Äôt really sunk in that it‚Äôs over now.

The students in this Python class were beginners - they had all done some programming in block-based languages like Snap!, but none of them had taken AP CS yet, to give you an idea of where they were at experience-wise.

As one of the final projects of the year, we had them write a little roguelike (a term with many definitions, which here I‚Äôm using to mean ‚Äúa game where you‚Äôre an @ sign and you wander around an ASCII art world‚Äù). We gave them some starter code and one of my usual project writeups and turned them loose.

This is what the starter code does when you run it:

You‚Äôre the @ sign, you can move around, you can‚Äôt go through walls. Great game, right?

We had the kids start by changing my terrible controls to be WASD-based, which turned out to be a good way for them to get their bearings - this was their first time being dumped into a (tiny) legacy codebase, and having to change the controls forced them to read the code and figure out where the relevant moving parts were.

After that, we walked them through how to add a goal space that ends the game if you get to it, then showed them how to add some dumb monsters that just sit there and don‚Äôt do anything. Once they had done that, we were like: okay, now make a game!

Here‚Äôs some of the cool stuff they made!

Coin Getter

You‚Äôre the smiley face, you want to get to the X, but there‚Äôs a door blocking the way to it - the door doesn‚Äôt open until you get all the coins first.

The program uses the ¬© symbol for its coins, and so when we were having the kids demo each other‚Äôs games on the projector at the end of the project, some kid in the peanut gallery shouted ‚Äúif you get all five copyright strikes, your channel gets taken down!‚Äù.

I thought that was pretty good.

Bait-And-Switch

In this one, you‚Äôre the √ñ, the ”Ås are enemy squids, the ·µπs are health potions, and your goal is to get to the next level, which is too big to fit on this page so I‚Äôll just show you the first level.

The squids don‚Äôt do anything, but notice how if you pick up a health potion, your health increases!

If you pick up the second health potion, though, your health decreases. This puzzled me for a bit, but I pieced it together - if you pick up the farthest-down health potion on the level, the game gets confused and thinks it‚Äôs a health potion and also a monster, and so it increments your health by 10 but then decrements it by 20 because that‚Äôs what bumping into a squid is supposed to do. Interesting little bug.

This game has a little trick to it - the door to the next level is actually the ‚ñê, but if you get confused and hit the + instead, the game insults you in big ASCII art and unceremoniously exits. I love it.

King Of THING

You‚Äôre the ‚òª, the ‚à©s are harmless barrels that you effortlessly smash through, the rs are rats, the gs are goblins. You can kill the rats and goblins, but it‚Äôs hard and you take a lot of damage doing it because you start off with really low attack power. If you pick up a ‚Ä†, though, now you have a dagger and can wreck ‚Äòem easily!

Once you make it to the next level, you can pick up a ‚úü (sword) to really boost your damage, and if your HP is low after fighting some goblins you can chug a ‚úö (health potion) to heal up. Be careful of the ‚ú† you‚Äôll pass on your way to the next floor of the dungeon - it‚Äôs a chainsaw, and if you touch it, you‚Äôll die!

After that, it‚Äôs time to fight the big boss himself: you‚Äôve gotta beat the king and take his crown! I love how this third level is structured, it‚Äôs so simple but somehow, like, evocative. It starts with a traditional ammo room so you just know you‚Äôre about to fight a scary boss, and I love the little corridor you have to squeeze through to get to the king - I actually got kinda scared on my way through it. It felt like anything could happen!

Favorite parts:

  • The little heart in the congratulations message
  • Kings Killed: 0

A-Maze-Ing

Look, I didn‚Äôt come up with these names, it‚Äôs not my fault.

I think I have RSI now.

Soccer

One kid made the starter code into a soccer game!

You‚Äôre the %, the $ is the AI enemy player and it chases the ball, the @ is the ball, and when you kick the ball there‚Äôs some randomness involved so sometimes you find yourself chasing after it and trying to get there before the AI does.

Other Cool Projects We Did This Year

Here are all the projects I put together for this class, in increasing order of difficulty. They start off assuming basically zero knowledge of Python, and slowly require more and more over time as the students learn about if-statements, loops, lists, etc.

  • Mad Libs
  • A guess-my-number game
  • Generated art with a pen plotter
  • A password generator
  • A password strength checker
  • A Caesar cipher program
  • Tic-Tac-Toe with an AI opponent
  • Blackjack against an AI dealer
  • Roguelike (starter code)

I put a lot of time into these over the course of two years, and I‚Äôm really proud of how they turned out. Many many thanks to Tamara for her help and feedback.

If you‚Äôd like to use these projects in a classroom or for practice on your own, please feel free! Hit me up at jrrrheard@gmail.com if you have questions or want me to review your code, I‚Äôd be delighted to hear from you.

What‚Äôs Next For Me

This has been a really great time, but I feel like having a regular job again and having coworkers to hang out with, so I‚Äôm joining Ride Report as a senior engineer. They offered me the job back in April, and were kind enough to let me finish out the school year before my start date.

I‚Äôve been looking forward to this for a while, it‚Äôs going to be fun and I‚Äôm going to learn a lot. Down with cars!

  1. I was originally placed in this high school through an organization called TEALS. They‚Äôre accepting applications for the coming school year, so you should apply if this sounds like fun. It is fun!¬†↩

entry.title: Jobs
entry.content:
I think that it‚Äôs bad that people have to have jobs.

I don‚Äôt think that jobs are bad. I‚Äôve been spent the past couple of years without a job, and over that time I‚Äôve noticed a lot of things that I miss about employment. I miss having coworkers, I miss working on a long-term project, and I miss having a reason to get out of the house every day. I didn‚Äôt expect to miss anything about having a job, but I miss those things very much.1 I‚Äôm not trying to say that I think that jobs are a completely bad idea.

I think that it‚Äôs bad that people have to have jobs.

I‚Äôm not an economist, I‚Äôm not a historian, I don‚Äôt have any numbers to show you, I don‚Äôt have any relevant non-anecdotal experience that I can bring to bear on this topic. Usually when I make an argument, I like to have facts and figures to back it up, and I haven‚Äôt done that research here, and I understand that this makes my argument a not-very-good one.

I just have this gut feeling that it‚Äôs bad that we live in a world where people have to have jobs, and if they lose their job they get really scared, and maybe they can‚Äôt pay their medical bills or they become homeless, and their family suffers too, and they‚Äôre at 100% maximum stress constantly until they can find another job. I think that people should be able to choose to have a job, and I think that it‚Äôs bad that they‚Äôre instead forced to have a job.

This is not a post about universal basic income, although I do think that UBI‚Äôs an interesting idea, and I hope that we continue to experiment with it.2

I don‚Äôt know what we should be doing instead of our current system where everyone has to have a job. But humans are smart, and I‚Äôm sure that if we thought about it really hard we could come up with some more ideas and try them out. I know that this is a difficult and expensive problem, but I also think that it‚Äôs important that we identify it as a problem. I think that more people should be thinking and talking about this.

I think that it‚Äôs bad that people have to have jobs or else they starve and die. I think that we as a society should have an explicit goal of getting to a point where people no longer have to have jobs, and can instead choose how to spend their time. I‚Äôm surprised that that‚Äôs not currently a goal that people talk about on the news and at dinner parties. I think that we should talk about this more.

I expect that once people no longer have to have jobs, they‚Äôll be able to spend time on things that actually interest them instead of trading lots of years of their life for room and board. I expect that some people will vegetate and play video games all day, and some people will do drugs or whatever, but I also expect that a lot of people will get involved in their community, and in nonprofit-type organizations, and just generally have the time and energy to be able to really think about how to make the world around them better and then implement the ideas they come up with.

Those are just vague uninformed guesses. Nobody knows what would happen if we took our society and made it into one where people didn‚Äôt have to have jobs. I just think that it‚Äôs bad that people have to have jobs, and I think that we should be talking about this more.

I mean: If you were the president of the world, and you were in charge of figuring out how people spent their time and got their food and housing, would you have come up with this?

  1. Don‚Äôt worry, I completely recognize that I am very, very, very fortunate to be able to have this experience and learn that I miss these things. I don‚Äôt take this for granted.¬†↩

  2. I‚Äôm skeptical of people who say that UBI is a stupid idea because everyone needs to have a job because it‚Äôs good for the moral fiber or whatever. It‚Äôs very possible that we‚Äôll find a lot of things that are bad about UBI, but in my opinion it seems like a compelling enough idea that we should really try it out, because maybe the good things will vastly outweigh the bad, and maybe not many bad things will happen. I know that people are currently earnestly investigating UBI, and I‚Äôm glad that they‚Äôre doing that. I donate monthly to GiveDirectly‚Äôs basic income experiment.¬†↩

entry.title: Truthiness and Short-Circuit Evaluation in Python
entry.content:
Target audience: beginner programmers

In the high school Python class I‚Äôm helping out with, I‚Äôve noticed that students will often write a chunk of code that looks like this:




In this example, the student has a num variable whose value is some integer, and they‚Äôre trying to write some code that gets run if the integer is 5 or 6 or 7. The code snippet above seems reasonable at first glance, but it actually does something completely different from what the student would expect.



Let‚Äôs focus on the num == 5 or 6 or 7 part, because that‚Äôs the part that isn‚Äôt doing what the student expects. Here‚Äôs what Python sees when you write that code:





num == 5


or


6


or


7





I‚Äôm going to be using a lot of diagrams like this throughout this article. In these diagrams, a yellow box is a chunk of code that Python hasn‚Äôt evaluated yet. (‚ÄúEvaluated‚Äù basically means ‚Äúrun‚Äù.)



Notice how the first yellow box in that diagram is



num == 5



and the second box is



6



That second box isn‚Äôt num == 6‚Äîit‚Äôs just 6. That‚Äôs kind of weird! What does the number 6 do if you put it in an if statement? Read on to find out!



OK, so we‚Äôre trying to decipher this code:







Let‚Äôs start our analysis by figuring out what that code does when the num variable has the value 10.



Python starts by evaluating 10 == 5, which turns into False.





False


or


6


or


7





So at this point, our partly-evaluated expression is False or 6 or 7, and Python has to figure out whether or not that whole thing ends up evaluating to True, because we‚Äôre running this code as the condition part of an if statement.



What does Python do when it sees False or 6 or 7? In order to answer that question, we‚Äôll need to know about truthiness and short-circuiting.



Truthiness



You‚Äôre familiar with the values True and False. We call them ‚ÄúBooleans‚Äù, and we use them most often in if statements.




hungry = True

if hungry:
	print('try eating a slice of pizza')
else:
	print('must be nice')




Python doesn‚Äôt limit us to just using True and False as the condition for if statements, though‚Äîyou can put any expression in there. If you put something in an if statement‚Äôs condition section and it‚Äôs not True or False, Python will look at it and decide whether or not it‚Äôs ‚Äútruthy‚Äù.



According to the official documentation, everything in Python is considered truthy except for these things:



    
  
  • False
    • 
  
  • None
    • 
  
  • 0
    • 
  
  • Empty sequences, e.g. [], '', (), {}
    • 




You can use the built-in bool() function to see if something is truthy. Here are some examples:




print(bool(True))
print(bool(False))
print(bool('cat'))
print(bool([]))
print(bool(['pizza', 'tacos']))




That code snippet is interactive, so go ahead and mess around with those examples to convince yourself that you understand how truthiness works. Is 15 truthy?



Now that we know what truthiness is, let‚Äôs talk about short-circuit evaluation.



Short-Circuit Evaluation



The and and or operators in Python are short-circuit operators. To see what this means, let‚Äôs look at an example use of the or operator.







This is what Python sees before it starts evaluating that code:





1 == 1


or


1 == 2





Remember that if a box is yellow, that means that Python hasn‚Äôt evaluated it yet.



An or expression is truthy if at least one thing in it is truthy. An and expression is truthy if all things in it are truthy.



Since this is an or, Python evaluates each of the yellow boxes in order until it finds one that‚Äôs truthy. It starts by evaluating 1 == 1, which turns into True.





True


or


1 == 2





At this point, Python stops, because you‚Äôre in an or and it‚Äôs found something truthy! That‚Äôs what short-circuiting means. The whole or expression evaluates to True, because that‚Äôs the value of the first truthy thing in it.



Here‚Äôs how the official documentation describes or‚Äôs behavior:




  
it only evaluates the second argument if the first one is false.





Here, I‚Äôll prove it to you.



If you divide a non-zero number by zero, Python will throw an exception:




1 / 0




Now check out what happens if I put a 1 / 0 after a truthy thing in an or:




print(True or 1 / 0)




The program prints True and doesn‚Äôt evaluate the 1 / 0! To convince yourself that this works the way I claim it does, try changing that True to a False.



This matches the behavior we saw in our most recent diagram. Do you remember how the 1 == 2 box stayed yellow to indicate that Python hadn‚Äôt evaluated the code inside of it?



So, that‚Äôs what ‚Äúshort-circuiting‚Äù means when you‚Äôre using the or operator. The and operator is pretty similar to or, except that the official documentation says that and




  
only evaluates the second argument if the first one is true.





That makes sense, because and wants to make sure that both of its operands are truthy. If the sub-expression on the left-hand side of an and is falsey, then the whole and expression is falsey! In that situation, there‚Äôs no need to evaluate the sub-expression on the right-hand side.



Here are some more examples. Do they all behave the way that you expect?





1 == 2


and


2 == 2







1 == 1


and


1 == 2







1 == 1


and


2 == 2







1 == 2


or


1 == 1





Back to our buggy num code



Now that we know about truthiness and short-circuit evaluation, we can finally figure out what this code does!







What do you think will be printed out when that code is run?



Before we run it and find out for sure, let‚Äôs walk through one last set of diagrams using what we‚Äôve learned. Here‚Äôs what Python sees before it starts evaluating anything:





num == 5


or


6


or


7





Python begins by evaluating 10 == 5, which turns into False.





False


or


6


or


7





Next up, it evaluates 6. We saw earlier that all non-zero numbers are truthy, so now our diagram looks like this:





False


or


6


or


7





At this point, Python stops and says: hey, I found something truthy! And that‚Äôs what the entire expression evaluates to. The answer is 6!




num = 10

print(num == 5 or 6 or 7)




And so that‚Äôs why the code from the beginning of this article doesn‚Äôt do what our student expects. num == 5 or 6 or 7 will always evaluate to either True or 6, and so the code inside that if statement will always be run!




num = 10

if num == 5 or 6 or 7:
       1 / 0
else:
       print('safe!')




Wrapping up



Here are a few more examples‚Äîplay around with them and try adding some of your own!




print(False or [])
print(2 or False)
print(False or 0 or "hello")




Notice how if everything in an or is falsey, then the whole or expression will evaluate to the rightmost sub-expression.




print(False or 0)




If everything in an and is truthy, then the whole and expression will evaluate to the rightmost sub-expression.




print('cat' and 'dog')




Oh, and if you want to write some code that does what the student in our example actually wanted, try one of these:




num = 7

print(num == 5 or num == 6 or num == 7)
print(num in [5, 6, 7])
print(5 <= num <= 7)




By the way‚Äîwhat do you think this code does? Will it evaluate to True? If not, why not?

entry.title: Using Hypothesis and Pexpect to Test High School Programming Assignments
entry.content:
I‚Äôve been coming up with some fun projects for a beginner Python high school class. Most of these projects are simple command-line programs that prompt the user for some input, perform some calculation, and print some output. For instance, here‚Äôs the password checker project:

This program should prompt the user for their username, student ID, and password, and it should print out the string GOOD or BAD to indicate whether or not the password is ‚Äúvalid‚Äù; see the assignment writeup for more details.

Testing

When a student finishes their password checker, we need to examine it to see whether or not the student programmed it correctly. We have around thirty students, and the checker program needs to satisfy a variety of constraints, and students often don‚Äôt get them all right the first time, so each student will usually submit several versions of the checker.

Testing submitted password checkers a jillion times by hand (‚Äúdoes the latest version of Jane‚Äôs checker correctly reject 'abcd'? How about '$!@#5555'?‚Äù) sounded pretty awful, so I decided to write a program to do this for us.

These students hadn‚Äôt learned about functions yet, so their programs didn‚Äôt have an is_password_good(password) function that I could import and unit-test. Instead, I needed to write code that would run the student‚Äôs program, send it several lines of input, and read its output.

My first instinct was to use the subprocess library to do this, but I had trouble getting that to work. I needed to send a line to the program, then wait and then send another line, and then wait and send a third line; but the subprocess library‚Äôs API isn‚Äôt particularly well-suited for situations where you want to send a program more than one line of input. I Googled around and found a bunch of StackOverflow questions written by people in my exact situation, and the answers all said to use pexpect instead.

Pexpect

Pexpect is a library that lets you start a program, feed it as many lines of input as you want, and read as many lines of output as you want.

Here‚Äôs how to use pexpect to operate the password-checker program you saw earlier:1




Once I had that working, I wrote some standard unit tests.







I hand-wrote around twenty assertions like those and called it a day. It was very satisfying to run the resulting tests, and I felt great about the amount of time that they would save.



A week later, though, I stumbled across Hypothesis and realized that my tests had a lot of room for improvement.



Hypothesis



Hypothesis is a property-based testing library. Its homepage says:




  
Hypothesis runs your tests against a much wider range of scenarios than a human tester could, finding edge cases in your code that you would otherwise have missed.





Earlier, I showed you a test called test_too_short_rejected(). That test asserts that the password 'X$3' is marked ‚ÄúBAD‚Äù, because the password checker is supposed to reject passwords that are shorter than eight characters.







This is an example-based test, which means that I wrote it by hand using an example too-short password that I came up with off the top of my head.



This test is actually pretty flimsy, because it only checks to see if 'X$3' is rejected‚Äîbut if the student‚Äôs checker program incorrectly allows a seven-character-long password like 'X$12345', my test won‚Äôt catch that bug, because I didn‚Äôt think to include that example in my test. I could add more examples to my test, but that isn‚Äôt very fun; and even if I did think really hard and came up with five more examples, my test still wouldn‚Äôt be very exhaustive, because students are very good at coming up with bugs that I wouldn‚Äôt think to test for.



How To Use Hypothesis



Let‚Äôs use Hypothesis to improve this test. We‚Äôll start by adding the @given decorator to our test function.







When Hypothesis sees a test that‚Äôs annotated with the @given decorator, it runs that test a bunch of times. This test‚Äôs decorator says that the test wants a random password argument; so each time Hypothesis runs this test, it‚Äôll generate a random password, and will supply it to the test via the test function‚Äôs newly added password parameter.



We‚Äôre halfway there‚Äîall we have to do now is tell Hypothesis how to actually generate too-short passwords.



A too-short password is a string with some characters in it. Those characters can be the lowercase letters a-z, the uppercase letters A-Z, the digits 0-9, and some specific symbols given in the assignment writeup. The student‚Äôs password-checker program is supposed to reject passwords that are shorter than eight characters, so a too-short password can have at most seven characters.



Here‚Äôs how to say that to Hypothesis:







st.text() returns a strategy, which is an object that Hypothesis can use to generate random data. Hypothesis has a ton of these that you can use to generate all sorts of stuff.2



When we give short_password_strategy to the @given decorator, Hypothesis will generate random passwords like these:







That‚Äôs all there is to it‚Äînow that we know how to generate random too-short passwords, we can convert our example-based test to a property-based test.







We‚Äôre done! That wasn‚Äôt so hard.



Here‚Äôs what our test looks like in action:3





That‚Äôs a lot more thorough than assert_bad('X$3', checker).



Before I wrap up, I‚Äôd like to tell you about two of my favorite Hypothesis features: shrinking and the example database. Both of these features are also described in Anatomy of a Hypothesis Based Test, which is well worth a read.



Shrinking



If Hypothesis generates a random value that causes your test to fail, it will then attempt to shrink that value, which means that it tries to find a ‚Äúsimpler‚Äù value that still causes your test to fail.



For instance, if Hypothesis finds that a student‚Äôs password checker incorrectly accepts the too-short password',xcc69', it will usually shrink that password down to 'A1!'. That‚Äôs because even when students forget to implement the at-least-eight-characters rule, they still often remember to implement the rule that says that passwords must contain ‚Äúat least three categories of character‚Äù; and so for programs like that, 'A1!' is the simplest possible input that causes the test to fail.



This is a really great quality-of-life feature that makes test failures much easier to decipher. It doesn‚Äôt make much of a difference in this example, but it‚Äôs a lifesaver when you‚Äôre dealing with large/complex inputs.



Example Database



When I first learned about Hypothesis, I was concerned that its randomness would be a liability. If Hypothesis gives my tests random input every time, and the program I‚Äôm testing has a failure that‚Äôs only triggered by a rare input, then won‚Äôt my tests sometimes pass and sometimes fail?



Hypothesis solves this problem by saving previously seen failures in a folder called .hypothesis/examples and trying them again the next time you run your tests. This ‚Äúexample database‚Äù feature means that once your Hypothesis test fails, it‚Äôll keep on failing until you fix the bug. Which is an extremely good thing.



What It Feels Like To Use Hypothesis



It feels really good.



Our Hypothesis tests have caught a really amazing amount of bugs in students‚Äô programs, many of which were things I simply would not have caught with example-based tests. One student‚Äôs password checker turned out to use the hand-crafted string abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwyz, which if you‚Äôll look closely you may notice is missing the letter x. Lots of little tiny bugs like this.



Hypothesis tests‚Äîat least, the basic ones I‚Äôve written so far‚Äîaren‚Äôt hard to write. In fact, writing them is pretty fun! When I write Hypothesis tests, my tests find a lot of bugs; I tell our students to fix their bugs; and I feel like a happy calm wizard.



You should try using Hypothesis the next time you‚Äôre writing tests in Python. If you use a different programming language, check this page to see if your language has a good property-based testing library. If it does, try it out!














  
    
    
  1. 
      
    It‚Äôs interesting to note that pexpect.popen_spawn.PopenSpawn uses the subprocess library under the hood. The subprocess library can‚Äôt easily be used to send/receive multiple lines to/from a program, but it seems to still be a fine primitive to use when building a system that can do that.¬†↩
    
    
    2. 
    
  2. 
      
    If you‚Äôd like to generate instances of classes defined in your program, you might find this guide handy.¬†↩
    
    
    3. 
    
  3. 
      
    In this recording, I‚Äôve put Hypothesis into verbose mode using the HYPOTHESIS_VERBOSITY_LEVEL environment variable so that we can see the random passwords that it generates. On the rare occasions when I write a Hypothesis test that passes the first time it‚Äôs run, I like to put Hypothesis into verbose mode and run the test again to convince myself that I haven‚Äôt made some sort of generation mistake.¬†↩
